Hans being the villain all along was a legit shock! I totally trusted him.
Olaf is the best sidekick. 'Some people are worth melting for.' Crying.
The act of true love being Anna saving Elsa, not a kiss, was a game-changer for Disney.
The animation of the ice and snow is just gorgeous.
Kristoff's 'lost in the woods' 80s power ballad was the funniest part of the movie.
I love the relationship between Anna and Elsa. It feels so real.
The trolls trying to marry Anna and Kristoff is hilarious and awkward.
The Duke of Weselton and his two thugs are such goofy villains.
Elsa's ice palace is a work of art. I want to live there.
The chemistry between Anna and Kristoff is so much better than with Hans.
Anna's heart freezing and her slowly turning to ice was so intense.
Sven is the best reindeer. He has more personality than some human characters.
The moment Anna freezes solid to block Hans' sword is absolutely iconic.
This movie has some of the best songs in any Disney movie.
Elsa striking Anna in the heart by accident was such a 'oh no' moment.
'Do You Want to Build a Snowman?' is secretly the saddest song in the whole movie.
Hans leaving Anna to die was stone-cold villainy. My jaw dropped.
The whole opening with the ice harvesters is such a cool way to start the film.
Olaf finally getting his own personal snow flurry at the end is so wholesome.
The way Elsa's powers are tied to her emotions is a great metaphor for anxiety.
The reveal that love can thaw the eternal winter was a beautiful message.
The trolls are kinda creepy but also kinda cute? Idk.
Elsa running away to the North Mountain is her big 'I'm free' moment.
The coronation scene is so tense. You can just feel Elsa trying to keep it together.
Kristoff's family being a bunch of rocks is a weird but funny twist.
The parents' death at sea was so sudden and tragic.
The way Elsa accidentally freezes all of Arendelle is a great setup for the main conflict.
'Love is an Open Door' is a bop until you realize it's a villain song.
The final scene with the whole kingdom skating together is so heartwarming.
The designs of Anna's and Elsa's dresses are iconic.
The twist with Hans makes you re-evaluate every single thing he did in the first half of the movie.
Olaf's song about summer is so innocently dark, it's hilarious.
The moment when Kristoff races back to save Anna... my heart.
The sibling relationship is the true love story here.
Marshmallow the snow monster was a cool surprise.
The way Anna just punches Hans off the boat at the end is so satisfying.
The trolls' song 'Fixer Upper' is so catchy.
Elsa learning to control her powers through love instead of fear is the whole point.
The fact that Anna was so desperate for love she'd marry a guy she just met makes so much sense given her childhood.
When the white streak in Anna's hair appears, you know things are getting serious.
Oaken's trading post scene is comedy gold. 'Yoo-hoo!'
The moment Elsa realizes what she's done and flees is so powerful.
I can't believe the trolls just erased Anna's memories of Elsa's magic.
Hans revealing his plan to Anna while she's dying is peak villain monologue.
The movie is a great exploration of sisterly love and sacrifice.
Elsa bringing back summer and creating a personal snow cloud for Olaf shows she's finally in control.
The animation on Elsa's magic is just mesmerizing.
That moment when Anna chooses to save her sister over herself still gets me every time.
The whole 'conceal, don't feel' mantra is such a sad way to live.
Kristoff realizing he loves Anna and turning back is such a great character moment.
The details in the ice palace are incredible.
The reveal about Hans's 12 older brothers explains so much about his motives.
The ending, where Elsa can finally be herself without fear, is so freeing.
Sven trying to get Kristoff to go back to Anna is so sweet.
The final scene proves that family love is the most powerful magic of all.
The way the ice thaws as Elsa learns to love is a great visual metaphor.
Hans' betrayal is one of the best Disney villain twists ever.
The first time Elsa lets her powers go is such a beautiful and liberating scene.
The memory wipe explains why Anna has no idea about Elsa's powers.
The 'frozen heart' from the opening song was foreshadowing all along!
Olaf telling Anna that Kristoff is the one she loves is so pure.
The whole plot is kicked off by Anna's impulsiveness and Elsa's fear. Great character writing.
The way Elsa's powers react to her fear is so well done.
The final battle in the blizzard is epic.
The trolls basically gave the worst advice ever. 'Fear will be your enemy.' No kidding!
The moment the ice starts to spread in Anna's hair is a great visual ticking clock.
The climax subverts all the classic Disney tropes. It's not about the prince.
I love that the movie is about repairing a broken sibling bond.
Elsa creating Marshmallow out of anger and fear shows how dangerous her powers can be.
The whole kingdom thinking Elsa is a monster is so tragic.
The moment Anna's statue starts to thaw... chills.
Arendelle is such a beautiful kingdom, even when it's frozen.
The reveal that Hans was just using Anna to get to the throne was so cruel.
The music is what really elevates this movie to another level.
The ending is so satisfying because both sisters finally find their place and their happiness.
Sven and Olaf are the best comedic duo.
The way Elsa's fear manifests as sharp, dangerous ice is a great visual cue.
The whole movie is a lesson in not shutting people out.
Anna's determination to save her sister is so admirable.
The visuals of the eternal winter are beautiful but also eerie.
The act of true love being selfless sacrifice rather than romantic love is the key.
I can't listen to 'Love is an Open Door' without getting mad now.
The way Elsa thaws everything proves that love is the answer to her fear.
This movie has a great message about embracing who you are.
Olaf lighting the fire to keep Anna warm, knowing he'll melt, is true friendship.
The trolls are kinda sketchy but their hearts are in the right place, I guess.
The final confrontation with Hans on the ice is so dramatic.
A perfect blend of music, emotion, and stunning animation.
The resolution of Anna and Elsa's relationship is the real 'happily ever after'.
The side characters like Oaken add so much charm.
The 'frozen heart' curse can only be broken by an act of true love. Masterful storytelling.
The way the film plays with fairytale expectations is brilliant.
The ending shows that true strength comes from love and acceptance, not isolation.
The entire plot is a metaphor for mental health and learning to accept yourself.
Hans' double-cross is a legendary Disney moment.
'For the First Time in Forever' really captures the loneliness both sisters feel.
The climax proves that it's Elsa's love for Anna that allows her to control her powers.
